posts.cooked:
Hi all,

I’m interested in hearing your opinions before my team regroups to make a decision. Recently, we participated in the North Star Regional with our robot, which featured a tank drive and shallow climb capabilities. Our robot performed well, functioning reliably and allowing us to address and fix any issues quickly. We adjusted our autonomous programming and improved our shallow climb performance. Although we didn’t align with an alliance, we had a great experience and learned a lot. Last year, our robot underperformed significantly, failing to move effectively on the field or defend, so this was a significant improvement.

Our team has discussed exploring alternative drive systems, such as swerve, but our coach suggested starting with Mecanum as a stepping stone. He believes Mecanum offers better maneuverability and would help us adapt to the field better, especially when aligning with stations or reversing. While I’m concerned about the limited off-season time available, I believe attempting Mecanum could enhance our robot's performance before potentially transitioning to swerve in the future, which I genuinely admire for its advanced features.

Switching to Mecanum might resolve our navigation challenges, which were often complicated with our current system. However, I’m curious if this switch would complicate tasks like alignment and backing up. In the long term, I’d love to fully adopt swerve for its superior handling, but for now, I’m open to Mecanum as an intermediate solution to build foundational skills.

Feedback from you all would be invaluable as we plan our approach. How does switching to Mecanum sound, and do you see benefits over our current setup? Let me know your thoughts—I’m eager to hear how we can improve our robot’s mobility for future competitions.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
My response to your coach would be:

"Mecanum is not a step on the way to swerve. Swerve is a completely different drivetrain, with a completely different setup. Mecanum will be 'easier' to install on a kit chassis, even with the extra gearboxes required; however, swerve is rapidly becoming easier to do given the right parts. Either way, mecanum requires a completely different mechanical and programming setup than swerve does. As a matter of practicality, mecanum that isn't driven like a swerve should really be a tank drive, and mecanum that is driven like a swerve is going to be completely outclassed by every swerve on the field."

What I would NOT tell him is: "Some teams see mecanum and instantly remove that team from any pick lists." Even though it’s true, it’s still not something that I think needs to be said.

One other thing: An anonymous poster mentioned that "OC Regional has 1 tank and 1 mecanum. Everything else swerves, including the rookie." That's interesting because the data shows that swerve is currently the dominant drive style. Rookie teams are pulling off swerve drives, and you might want to check out the linked thread for more details.

I’m going to emphasize this: Rookie teams are successfully implementing swerve drives. The data indicates that swerve is currently the most popular choice among teams. Regarding your question about switching to mecanum, I would not recommend it. It’s actually a downgrade compared to what you already have. If I were you, I’d stick with your current setup and aim to get the best swerve system available before the offseason competition begins.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
We spent from our rookie year (2015) to last season as a tank. Towards the end, we moved from CIMs to NEOs for our drive motors. This change was significant. We also switched from white wheels to black ones for improved traction.

At the end of the school year last year, we transitioned to swerve. Over the past few years, we had been gradually building the swerve system, purchasing components as our budget allowed. This year, we finally used swerve for the first time.

There is a knowledge gap we needed to address, and we are still learning.

In summary: If you desire a Corvette, never settle for a Chevette. There are numerous swerve options available, and coding isn’t overly challenging. Additionally, there is ample support available if you encounter any issues.

I would encourage anyone considering the leap into swerve. You won’t regret it; it’s an experience you’ll cherish forever.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Doug Kavner
posts.cooked: I came across this topic and initially thought it might be a repost from 2019. Mecanum can serve as a fun academic exercise when exploring drivetrain history, especially when there's nothing else to do. However, it's not practical for competitive use today. Focusing on mechanical systems during the off-season can be a good idea. While the fundamentals are straightforward, there's still much to learn regarding tuning, driver practice, precise autocross navigation, and maintenance—details you probably don't want to handle during competition season. After four years of experience, we've found that there are always new things to uncover. Mecanum won't magically improve your performance overnight.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: My opinion is that mecanum is not a viable option. If it is at all affordable for your team, I would recommend looking at examples of successful teams like 9092 and 9543. These teams built advanced robots during their rookie years and significantly improved their performance in year two by incorporating features like a swerve drivebase.

Driver practice will be far more impactful in terms of performance than any drivetrain. If your driver can achieve peak efficiency with your current drivetrain, you will perform well. Additionally, consider enhancing software to support your driver. Each Venom has internal encoders; utilizing them can improve automation or driver aids. Mechanum vehicles lose efficiency and speed when moving in non-perpendicular directions, often forcing drivers to operate like a tank due to inefficiencies or drivetrain misalignment, which may also lead to overheating. This reduces both speed and acceleration in such movements. Moreover, wheel odometry becomes unreliable under these conditions, necessitating dead wheels. Mechanum vehicles are highly sensitive to mass distribution, further complicating their operation.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: In 2015, towards the end of the rookie season, we transitioned from using CIMs to NEOs for motors. Off topic but… Ah, never mind, I see what you mean. Regardless, your point still holds: a simple motor upgrade can have significant impacts when moving from basic CIMs. However, there's a slight detail to consider—the NEO was still just an idea in development around 2014–2015. From 2015 to 2017, there were some fascinating and innovative drivetrain ideas floating around, including the 775Pro gearbox and other cool advancements.
Extremely important: Do not use Mechanum. What was mentioned earlier about avoiding "do not pick" lists is accurate.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked: We switched to NEOs in 22 for our drivetrain. When you are a small, underfunded team, you do what you can.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Lauchlin
posts.cooked: In my opinion, in today’s FIRST Robotics Competition, if a team can perform a swerve, they should do so. If they’re unable to execute a swerve, the next best option is to utilize the kitbot chassis. Any alternative strategy beyond these two options isn’t as effective from a competitive design standpoint.

posts.name: Richard Wallace
posts.cooked:
To the OP:

I watched your North Star matches. I’ve been involved in the design of numerous FIRST Robotics Competition robots and have helped start several FIRST Robotics Competition teams since 1996, with over 40 years of motor engineering experience. Your team performed well with the basic L1 design this year. Additional pushing power could have provided a slight advantage, while a mecanum drive would have been a significant disadvantage.

FIRST Tech Challenge is a great program, and mecanum drive works well there. In Michigan, FTC is limited to middle school teams, and many of our top FIRST Robotics Competition students began their journey in FTC. However, none of those students would recommend mecanum drive for an FRC robot.

posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked:
This is as comprehensive an answer as anyone could give, and I agree with all parts of it. OP, don’t bother with Mecanum. It’s not worth the headache nowadays. I’m not convinced it was ever worth the headache. If your center of gravity isn’t perfectly centered over the middle of the robot, you will never, ever drive straight unless you do weird stuff in your code to compensate. This makes programming a competent Mecanum drive far more difficult than it looks on the surface.

I spent 2 years mentoring 3007, a team from your neck of the woods who insisted on Mecanum year after year. We had mentors who were well-versed in wrangling Mecanum’s quirks in code. We had good habits around checking rollers for debris between matches. WE STILL NEVER DROVE STRAIGHT.

Back then, there was (sort of) a case for Mecanum. Yes, it was fiddly, you never drove straight, and you always moved slower than everyone else, but you couldn’t get t-boned and tight field geometry wasn’t a hindrance. Now, Swerve delivers on all of Mecanum’s advantages, does a better job at those advantages than Mecanum can, and has none of the fiddly in-competition annoyances.

The only game I can think of where Mecanum could have had a net advantage over tank was 2015—a game unlike any other in the RIO era, and Mecanum STILL didn’t work great because the weight of the totes threw your CoG totally out of whack while you placed a stack. You either couldn’t drive straight while going to the feeder, or you couldn’t drive straight while placing a stack. Pick your poison.

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
Concurring opinion. It is possible to have an effective and inspiring mecanum robot. Team 6167 used an Everybot mecanum robot to perform captain roles at their last two FSC events, though there are some considerations:  
They were also able to avoid interference and operate the processor algae, which added additional value. Having the Everybot climb was particularly advantageous in FSC compared to other events, as several top teams chose not to include climbing. This year’s game was relatively more mecanum-friendly due to shorter sprints, which mitigated the loss of power compared to games like Crescendo or Charged Up. This wasn’t their first time competing with a mecanum.  

Additionally, while I criticize the swerve tax and how the mere presence of a swerve affects many teams' build strategies, mecanum continues to improve in 2025. Unless there’s a significant rule change for 2026, there are two viable options in my view:  
Using the AM14U6 chassis from the kit with HiGrip wheels, paired with your preferred Toughbox Mini gear ratio and drivetrain motor. If you anticipate high wheel wear, consider upgrading to the 8WD kit. Implementing a Commercial, off-the-shelf swerve, when done correctly, offers a higher competitive ceiling. However, if your resources or capacity are limited, the former configuration remains a reasonable alternative.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: #31 on the scoreboard but #1 in your heart.

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked: Spend all the time you'd invest making mecunum work on fundraising for a swerve drive. With tools like Yet Another Generic Swerve Library (YAGSL) and others available, the primary barrier to creating a functional swerve chassis is mainly the financial aspect—securing enough funds.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
If your center of gravity isn’t perfectly centered over the middle of the robot, driving straight would require unusual adjustments in the code, making mecánico (mecanum) drives much harder than they seem. Thank you for clarifying why mecánico can be challenging instead of just advising against it. In ideal conditions, mecánico is usually streamlined for quick setup and functionality, leading to a holonomic drive train. For this year’s Kitbot, the center of gravity is relatively stable, potentially making mecánico a viable option. However, you’d still need to use dual gearboxes—one per wheel—adding to costs slightly.

That said, the most frustrating issue arises when the frame isn’t perfectly aligned. If it tilts slightly, the bot could lose balance on two opposite wheels, affecting movement in both axes. This happened to us in 2015, the first and last time we attempted mecánico. We defaulted to a straightforward tank drive until 2024, often overwhelmed by swerves, and mecánico wasn’t reconsidered seriously afterward.

An interesting cost-saving tip: only two swerve modules are needed for a swerve bot. Placing them diagonally and using omnidirectional wheels for the remaining corners works flawlessly in our practice bot. While most builder tools expect four modules, you can ignore two and adjust parameters accordingly. Using Yagsl, we’ve successfully operated both our practice and competition bots without code modifications. While this approach works for testing, it’s not recommended for official competitions.

If your center of gravity isn’t perfectly centered over the middle of the robot, you will never, ever drive straight unless you do weird stuff in your code to compensate. Actually, mecanum drives rarely drive straight even if the CG is centered and your frame is built to good tolerances unless you solve a rather complicated controls problem. The easiest way to demonstrate it is to drive a mecanum drive bot forwards, then suddenly sideways. Two of the wheels need to swap directions, but because the wheels and robot has inertia and non-zero latency, the robot skews and you aren’t straight anymore. This isn’t unsolvable, but it is outside the means of almost every FIRST Robotics Competition team to solve, hence why most mecanum FIRST Robotics Competition and FIRST Tech Challenge bots don’t drive straight to some degree or another unless driven slowly. It is possible to solve this problem (I’ve personally done so); it’s really hard (you need to use a Cartesian-space inverse dynamics controller, while extrapolating out latency and avoiding voltage, current, and traction saturations). Swerve is less susceptible to these issues due to having more traction and throwing 400W brushless motors at the problem.

I would not recommend mechanum if you're looking to build a more competitive robot. While it is primarily designed for FTC robots, mechanum allows your robot to be more easily pushed around. In one of our competitions this year, there was only one robot that used mechanum, and it was frequently pushed by both defending robots and the bots it was trying to defend, resulting in it being placed on our no-pick list.

posts.name: Benjamin Miller
posts.cooked: I’m not trying to dissuade you from a learning opportunity. However, our team has used Mecanum once, back in the COVID year. Despite no defense, it was flashy for a team that couldn’t run swerve. I would highly recommend trying out swerve if you can gather the funds. There are many excellent tools available. For coding, there’s YAGSL, yet another generic swerve library, and SDS, Swerve Drive Specialties, which operates quite straightforwardly. Just don’t place magnets upside down. However, it can be costly, and our team is fortunate to have supportive sponsors. I’d suggest looking for a grant specifically for a swerve base. If they recognize the innovation and STEM behind your project, it could help secure the necessary funding.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Erich posted a new thread in the General Forum discussing FRC pet peeves: what really grinds your gears? He mentioned that the correct spelling is "mecanum".

link_counts.title: FRC pet peeves: what really grinds your gears?

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
Driver practice will be far more impactful in terms of performance than any drivetrain. If your driver can reach peak efficiency with your current drivetrain, you will do well.  

Drive practice is critically important and swerve gives you two big advantages toward this goal.  

(1) Building a swerve drive base is dead easy. Cut 4 2x1 tubes to the appropriate lengths, bolt on your modules, and cut a quick and dirty belly pan out of 5mm plywood. Attach your electronics. Once you decide on a robot size, you should be able to get started with driving in a day or two.  

(2) Swerve provides "field-oriented" (as opposed to "robot-oriented") controls, making driving so much easier.  

This was how we built our "first" swerve, which we called "Barbie Bot."
